title: How to write a 5 minute speech about myself - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A. Illustrate Whatever you want to tell the audience, don't tell it literally, give instances / examples that prove it. For example if you want to share with the audience that you are an extremey patient person, don't tell them "I'm a very patient". Tell them an instance when you displayed this extreme patience: "I often wait for my friends for 2 hours without getting annoyed at all". Stories Facts tell stories sell. Use stories to get the audience members' interest and to make your points memorable. Whether you are talking about your years growing up, job, school, parents, family, hobbies, self, share in the form of a story. Think of all the memorable lessons / messages that you have learned from others, aren't they all in the form of stories in your head? Relevance Know your audience members and find out a little on their background. Are they in a particular industry? Do they share the same common interests? What do they want or need to know? Given any opportunity to do a sharing / speech / training, I always make it a point to share something with the audience that will benefit them. It can still be about them knowing you but more importantly what lesson / experience can you share with them to add value to their lives? If you're speaking to a group of IT developers whom you intend to be a part of, there's no need to talk about your pet. There's no relevance and not enough time in a short 5-min speech. You can talk about video games, about your past projects, some skilled programming friend you know, the future of IT, etc. Plus, you can talk about what you have learned from those experiences, perhaps they could learn about it from your speech as well. Length A 5-minute speech is extremely short. You can consider this format that I usuall use for up to 7-minute speech. Introduction - 40 seconds to 1 min Body - 3 points (stories) of around 1 min each. Perhaps 1 about you, 1 about your family, and 1 about your job (or aspiration). Conclusion - 1 minute On average, we speak 2-3 words per second. So for 5 minutes, 300 seconds, you have a maximum of 900 words for your script. Humour You must include some humour in your speech, at least 1 laughter point for the audience. Humour engages and entertains the audience. When they are entertained, they would like you that little bit more. Once they like you, they would remember you. If they remember you, they remember the message. Isn't that what we all strive for? Work the audience Get the audience to participate at least once in your speech, especially at the start. Ask them a simple question that they have to answer. Or at least ask them a rhetorical question that gets them thinking. It's preferable to get them answer "Yes" to whatever question you're asking. Positivity works in your favour. You could also get the audience to say some keywords after you. Funny or catchy phrase maybe. “I eat to live, not live to eat”. Write for the ear, not the eyes While preparing the script, read out your every sentence. Make sure they sound alright when verbally spoken. For example, we would write nevertheless, however, etc. In real conversations, we just use 'but'. Also, write and speak in shorter sentences and simple words. Unlike reading, audience members can't go back to your previous sentence or point if they miss something.  All the best!

5 min is easy. Break it into parts. Make it relatable. A lesson learned. Here’s the parts: -Family lineage Start w your parents and, if their story is interesting, even add your grandparents. Everyone likes to hear about one’s lineage, particularly if yours involves your people coming here - a success story, hardships overcome, etc. A special relative story (everyone loves a special mom or dad story) while you were growing up is usually a winner. Or funny family stories that involved you or at least impacted you. You have to be in, or related to, these background stories. -Wife / Husband and Kids Who doesn’t like to hear tributes to a spouse or what wonderful kids you have (although, be careful hyping the kids too much; people can become competitive RE their own). Emphasis is on love and togetherness. Your inspirations. -Finally, yourself!! Ok now you’ve set the stage: you’ve won the audience over w a funny grandma or dad story, with how much your spouse means to you and you’ve given a shout out to your kids. … 3 minutes has passed by now. Now it’s time for ““you.” First, EVERYONE has to have at least one interesting thing about themselves. And you only need 2 min to do this now. Be humble, humorous, and self effacing but confident in telling them at least one interesting thing about yourself. And a lesson learned you can share that the audience will relate to. Write out bullet points to practice each of the above parts beforehand but DO NOT read them at speech time. This type of speech comes from the heart - w eye contact - not from a page or an index card. Piece of cake!! Good luck.

Here is a method for writing a quick speech outline. It is a skeleton, but if you write out what I describe, you have your speech 75% written, and it should only take about 5 minutes: Constructing an Instant Speech. Can you fill out the following information? Topic: A. Introduction: How do you want to get the attention of the audience? A question i the fastest and easiest way. Choose opening. For quick speech use Question. a) Question Opening 2. What is a statement about your topic? 3. How do you want to organize your ideas? B. What is your 1st point? 1. What is more specific? 2. What is more specific? C. What is your 2nd point? 1. What is more specific? 2. What is more specific? D. What is your 3rd point? 1. What is more specific? 2. What is more specific? E. Conclusion 1. How do you keep your reader's attention focused on your main point? a) Choose one of the following. 1) Question 2) Anecdote 3) Joke. 4) Startling statement. 2. Restate your specific points? 1) 2) 3) 3. Restate your main point. For example: It took 15 minutes. It is not very elegant, but it is a skeleton that I can change. Topic: traveling I have done. A. Introduction: How do you want to get the attention of the audience? A question is the fastest and easiest way. Choose opening. For quick speech use Question. a) Question Opening: Have you lived in a foreign country? 2. What is a statement about your topic? I live in Southern California but I have traveled to the Philippines and Japan and lived in those countries for a time. 3. How do you want to organize your ideas? B. What is your 1st point? I grew up in Southern California 1. What is more specific? I was born in Riverside, California, a primarily agricultural area that grows oranges. 2. What is more specific? I went to elementery, junior high school, and college in Riverside then transferred to UCSB. C. What is your 2nd point? After graduating from UCSB, I was a Peace Corps Volunteer in the Philippines 1. What is more specific? The Philippines is hot and it rains a lot. 2. What is more specific? I lived in a place away from Manila in a small city called Dagupan D. What is your 3rd point? After the Philippines, I lived in Japan. 1. What is more specific? I was interested in Japan because it invaded the Philippines in World war II. The people in Japan are polite. 2. What is more specific? Japanes people are friendly and interested in the United States E. Conclusion 1. How do you keep your reader's attention focused on your main point? a) Choose one of the following. 1) Question 2) Anecdote People in the Philippines asked why the US helped Japan but not so much the Philippines, yet the Philippines was the Ally of the US, not Japan. 3) Joke. 4) Startling statement. 2. Restate your specific points? 1) I grew up in Southern California 2) After graduating from UCSB, I was a Peace Corps Volunteer in the Philippines 3) After the Philippines, I lived in Japan. 3. Restate your main point. I live in Southern California but I have traveled to the Philippines and Japan.

Here’s a good tip: The novel David Copperfield by Charles Dickens starts out with a chapter entitled “I Am Born.” Don’t start that way. At least half the other people writing five-minute speeches about themselves will start with when and where they were born, what their families are like and perhaps where they went to school. Don’t start that way. Start by saying, “There are three things that you need to know about me: I always notice the weather; I never notice how people are dressed; and I’m always ready to meet someone for coffee.” Or: Tell people what you enjoy most in a typical day and what you enjoy least. Or: Explain how and why you behave differently from all your brothers and sisters. An approach like that (like just one of those, to be clear) will help you organize something that everyone will enjoy and remember. In a five-minute speech, you can work in the necessary minimum details about your hometown, education and professional background after about three minutes and 30 seconds, but you can mention all those things without stressing them unduly. Don’t start with being born.

You can begin by making a draft of the speech. Include the main points and keep them in mind so that it becomes easier while speaking. So, basically you can mention about your hobbies in a descriptive way depending on the scenario. Consider all the aspects like the audience, how long should you be speaking and the purpose of the speech. DRAFTCreate a draft using the pointers for your speech. Know the purpose of your speech and have a clear of idea of the purpose behind the speech. PRIORITIZEAlways make the layout keeping in mind the main points which you want to involve in your speech. Get a piece of paper - write down a few topics you wish to talk about. Perhaps your early life Maybe your current situation And your hopes and aspirations for the future Flesh them out with perhaps 100 words each Read it over - slowly out loud and time yourself aim for about 4 minutes Do it several times so that it comes out clear and understandable- don’t rush. Use a style you would use talking t a friend - no fancy words When you’re comfortable with it put it down on a small card as an aide memoir with just a few bullet points. Do not attempt to read your script - throw it away. Then when it comes to deliver your speech tell your audience what you’re going to tell them - then deliver your talk - then tell them what you’ve just told them - make sure that they know that you’ve finished - perhaps Thank You for your listening. Talk slowly with pauses and remember to smile.

Choose one small part of your life which illustrates your character and personality, perhaps a fun time you had with your family and/or friends, or something you did all alone. Map that incident out into a rough outline - first sentence (must catch the audience attention) - the body will give the body of the incident (how many paragraphs etc.) - the ending (make it short and crisp). Humour is always helpful, but don’t attempt it if you’re not sure that you’re being funny. Avoid over-used words such as ‘very’ or ‘really’ and avoid colloquialisms and slang speech, unless it is being used for special effect. Good luck!

Pretend you’re someone else critiquing yourself, even in front of a mirror. Interview yourself in the mirror by asking a question with eyes averted and then look at your face when you answer. Keep in mind you’re someone else. When you’re finished, you’ll either have the best speech anyone could write about you or be schizophrenic. Either way, the experience will be one you’ll be glad you participated in.
